page.title: 01The Lower Shin Valley
page.content: The River Shin flows south through a steep sided gorge. The river is famous for salmon, which may be seen leaping up the falls on their way to their spawning grounds. Much of the water which formerly flowed down the river was diverted by tunnel to the Power Station at Inveran forming part of a Hydroelectricity scheme completed in 1954. The valley is flanked by moorland to the east and forestry plantations to the west. Two roads follow the River Shin also the railway line, leading to Lairg. A road to the west coast follows the Oykel Valley. A hotel on the moor commands magnificent views of both valleys. The population of the area is very low, there being only a few dwellings near the Power Station and a few scattered crafts and converted cottages.
